where_to_read: IS there any better place to read

reviews.review_text: I didn't get the ending. It was completely confusing to me.Nine more words required. Yada yada yada blah blah.
One of Chandler's best. Delicious and hard to put down. Not as well known as some of his other "Marlowe" novels.
Not the greatest of Chandler novels but still a fun read. Typical cast of characters, none of whom have a conscience.
So many zigs and zags in Raymond Chandler's plots, plus wacky, cool and intriguing characters.
Raymond Chandler is premier novel writer. He tells a great story in a very literary style.
I was able to read this one through just because of who the author was. Mickey Spillane is much more readable. Chandler spends a hundred paragraphs describing flowers, stuff like that.
The Little Sister is wonderful. It's o old time California, a great mystery, plenty of grit, and absolute poetry at the same time.Never pass up a Raymond Chandler!
Always a pleasure to spend time with Raymond Chandler. A very odd duck but a good writer. Still has no equal.
It's a grim book written by a master of scene, and sentence.

title: The Little Sister
word_cloud: get end completely confuse word require blah blah best hard put not well know novel not greatest chandler novel still fun typical cast character none conscience so many zing sag plot wacky cool intriguing character premier writer tell great story literary style excellent writer genre able author much readable spends hundred paragraph describe flower stuff wonderful old time great mystery plenty grit absolute poetry pas always pleasure spend time odd duck good writer still equal grim write master scene sentence
summary:
In noir master Raymond Chandler's The Little Sister, a movie starlet with a gangster boyfriend and a pair of siblings with a shared secret lure private eye Philip Marlowe into the less than glamorous and more than a little dangerous world of Hollywood fame.

Chandler's first foray into the industry that dominates the company town that is Los Angeles.
story_arc:
Fortunes fall, but the protagonist
                    bounces back
